answers.author: Amanda Relyea
answers.text:
The chair of the ICMA Task Force on Manager Evaluations just gave me a call about something else, and I asked him about this. Like me, he had not heard of elected officials and department heads meeting together, but he said he does 360-degree evaluations too, and the elected officials always take the department heads’ comments into account, so this seems to be a more formal, dialogue-oriented version of that. 
The ICMA Task Force on Manager Evaluations is working on a handbook for the membership and elected officials, so, like you, I am curious whether anyone else is doing this (and what people think about it, even if they are not doing it).

Hello Richard,
I'm not sure if any other local governments are trying out this approach to manager evaluations, but I can provide you with information that can help you if you/the Town Council decide to try this approach.  
This is a great article from the July 2005 issue of PM.  Several local governments were surveyed for their approaches to manager evaluations.  The core components of successful evaluations are listed and methods for accomplishing an effective evaluation are highlighted:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/3602/Case_Study_Its_Gulp_Evaluation_Time
Penn State's College of Business has done some research on the effectiveness of skip-level meetings.  They find that they are most effective in one-on-one settings and help break down natural barriers between managers and employees:
http://research.smeal.psu.edu/news/skip-level-leaders-inhibit-employee-voice
I hope these help.
Gabe Brehm
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

A member of the Task Force on Manager Evaluations, John Duffy, just conducted an informal survey. Sixty-five responses were received from across the United States. No respondents indicated use of the "skipped-level" evaluation process.

answers.text:
I published the results of my national survey on evaluation methods council used to evaluate their managers in the 2002 Municipal Year Book.  Althought the data are from 2000, the response rate was 56% so you can get a nice snapshot of methods council used at that time and also see the techniques managers thought worked well.

author: Richard Douglas
text: My Town Council wants to begin skip level meetings (1-2 times per year) with my department heads, as part of the town manager evaluation process.  Trying to determine if anyone else is doing this.
title: skip level meetings
